title: Shares in Premier Farnell dive after profit warning
text:

Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 20:06 BST - UK Markets closed Shares in Premier Farnell dive after profit warning By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 15 minutes ago 21.69 +1.01 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in Premier Farnell (LSE: PFL.L - news ) hit their lowest level in six years after the electronics distributor issued a profit warning. 
Shares in Premier Farnell sank to their lowest level in six years yesterday, after a profit warning spooked investors and reignited speculation the electronics distributor could become a bid target. 
The FTSE 250 company now expects adjusted operating profit in the first half of the year to be down by about 10pc compared with the previous year, as sales growth per day slowed in both UK and Northern American markets in the second quarter. 
Rivals, including Electrocomponents (LSE: ECM.L - news ) , Grainger (LSE: GRI.L - news ) and Motion Industries, have all noted a similar weakness in North America. 
Premier Farnell’s management also revealed it had started a strategic review of the group’s operations, the outcome of which will be revealed in September, when interim results are released. 
While the profit warning concerned analysts, it also spurred bid speculation chatter. “The chances of a bid are now arguably higher,” Henry Carver, of Peel Hunt, said. 
Despite cutting costs, improving sales and changing the operating structure, attempts to salvage the distressed business model are not working, he added. 
“On its own it will continue to struggle, but it could be a strategic asset to a larger player”, Mr Carver said. 
Last month, activist investor GO Investment Partners upped its stake in the British company to 4.1pc . Sources in the City said yesterday’s statement, which revealed “flaws in the business model” could prompt GO to “agitate for a deal”. 
There has long been speculation of a tie-up between Premier Farnell and Electrocomponents but whether the latter’s new boss, Lindsley Ruth, has a merger on his agenda is uncertain. Analysts also said pressure on management could see Premier Farnell offload some of its non-core assets, such as brands CPC or MCM, to help the floundering company get in shape for a possible sale. 
The shares fell 26.6p, or 16pc, to 140p. 
All eyes were on GlaxoSmithKline (Other OTC: GLAXF - news ) as it reported its first set of quarterly results since buying Novartis’ vaccines unit and selling its cancer drugs unit to the Swiss group. GSK’s shares jumped 46p, or 3.5pc, to £13.75 after it beat second-quarter profit forecasts thanks to increased demand for its new drug to fight HIV. The pharma giant reported a 6pc increase in sales to £5.9bn. 
Analysts at UBS (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) said GSK’s “US sales performed very strongly”, citing the continued benefit from the launch of Flonase, an allergy nasal spray. However, foreign currency headwinds weighed on profitability, impacting it negatively by 220 basis points. 
Meanwhile, Hikma leapt 86p to £24.07 after a broker upgraded the stock following Tuesday’s announcement that it will buy US generics unit Roxane . Jefferies raised the target price to £26.15 from £21.34 and lifted its rating to “buy”. James Vane-Tempest, of Jefferies, said “the deal provides a platform and pipeline to grow its business with opportunities to create further value from potential synergies.” 
In the broader market, Britain’s benchmark index was boosted by an injection of strong corporate results and updates. The FTSE 100 climbed 75.72 points to 6,631. * Chinese markets bounce back as Beijing steps in British American Tobacco also surpassed analysts’ downbeat profit expectations, sending the shares 129p higher to £36.81. Nonetheless, revenue for the first half of the year fell by 5.9pc to £6.4m . 
While Eddy Hargreaves, of Canaccord Genuity (Other OTC: CCORF - news ) , reckons the results were reassuring, he said “longer-term concerns such as e-cigarette incursion, the potential introduction of plain packaging and volume attrition in the core business remain”. 
Two days after five brokers slashed their price targets , platinum producer Lonmin (LSE: LMI.L - news ) found itself back in the firing line. UBS lowered its guidance from 75p to 45p following Friday’s mine shaft closures. 
However, Danielle Chigumira, of UBS, does not believe the closure of the Hossy and Newman mine shafts will result in a significant decrease in unit costs in the long-term. The stock was changing hands at 55.6p by the close down 3.5p, or 5.9pc. 
Elsewhere, mounting speculation of a tie-up between InterContinental Hotels (Other OTC: ICHGF - news ) Group and US company Starwood continued to circle the City, with the latter’s stock advancing 1.4pc to £26.23. 
Fastjet (LSE: FJET.L - news ) slipped 1.1pc, after it issued a statement saying “it knows of no material trading reason for the recent share price movement”. The stock had fallen 7.5pc on Tuesday. 
Finally, Aim-listed Sable Mining climbed 2.1pc to 0.5p after it unveiled encouraging metallurgical results for its Nimba iron ore project in Guinea.
